title: Saks Fifth Avenue owner Hudson's Bay in $2.1b deal to go private
text:
Private equity firm Catalyst Capital Group, which earlier this year acquired a 16 per cent stake in Hudson's Bay and opposed Mr Baker's previous offer, was considering its next steps, according to a person familiar with the matter who asked for anonymity.

Another Hudson's Bay shareholder with a smaller, undisclosed stake, activist hedge fund Land & Buildings, was against the deal because it considered the price inadequate, according to another source.

"We can only imagine there is a plan here to create substantial value once the company goes private, and that plan has only been shown to 57 per cent of shareholders," said Francis Casale, a former Hudson's Bay director who owns about a 0.2 per cent stake in the company and also opposes the deal.

Saks Fifth Avenue was among a series of acquisitions by Hudson's Bay after executive chairman Richard Baker took the company public in 2012. AP

Hudson's Bay shares ended up 6.1 per cent at $C10.30, below the deal price, indicating that most investors believed the deal would be voted through by shareholders.

An independent valuation report by real estate services firms CBRE and Cushman & Wakefield valued Hudson's Bay real estate at $C8.75 per diluted share, helping Mr Baker's push to convince the special committee to a deal closer to his offer.

Hudson's Bay chief executive officer Helena Foulkes had said last year the real estate could be valued at as much as $US28 ($41) per share.

The founding family of another North American department store operator, Nordstrom, tried to take it private last year, but a special committee of the board rejected the $US8.4 billion offer.

Advertisement

While the completion of the take-private deal would be a victory for Mr Baker, it would also represent the latest chapter of the company's retreat from its ambitions to become a global retail powerhouse.

Mr Baker, 53, a real estate developer who turned to the retail business early in his career, acquired Hudson's Bay more than a decade ago through a private equity firm built by his father, Robert Baker.

When Mr Baker invested in Hudson’s Bay, he believed that one of its holdings, Canadian discount chain Zellers, was highly valuable, according to people familiar with his thinking at the time.

After inciting a bidding war between Walmart and Target for Hudson's Bay's Canadian discount chain Zellers, he inked a deal with Target for the stores.

"He’s a tireless dealmaker ... and a wonderful negotiator," said Marc Cooper, CEO of investment bank PJ Solomon, who worked for Hudson's Bay selling Lord & Taylor to start-up retailer Le Tote for $US100 million in August.

Mr Baker took Hudson's Bay public in 2012 with a $US365 million offering, and then completed a string of acquisitions, including Saks Fifth Avenue, now Hudson's Bay's most profitable business, for $US2.9 billion.

The executive has reportedly visited stores owned by Hudson's Bay around the world by private jet and often commutes to his office in downtown Manhattan by boat via the Hudson River from his home in Connecticut.

Hudson's Bay is now focusing on its core businesses, Saks, and the eponymous Hudson's Bay department store chain in Canada.

"What (Baker) didn't realise is how difficult it would be to run retail operations," Mr Cooper said.
